Story: It was almost midnight when my phone buzzed with a frantic call from Mark. His voice trembled as he explained his car had broken down on the highway, miles from home. “Can you come get me? I don’t know who else to call,” he pleaded. As his friend, I knew he counted on me, especially in moments like this. But as I glanced at the clock, my heart sank. Tomorrow was Sunday, and I had promised myself—and my church community—that I would be there for the early morning service. I hadn’t missed a week in months, and I knew how much it meant to my faith and to the people who expected me to show up, to worship, to serve. The weight of both roles pressed on me. Mark’s need was urgent, but so was my commitment to my faith. I sat on the edge of my bed, phone in hand, torn between the desperate voice of my friend and the quiet, steady call of my beliefs.
